facts.text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Rajasthan rejecting the application under section 66(2) of the Income-tax Act filed by the appellant

anchor.surface_text: Sikri, J. This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Rajasthan, rejecting the application under section 66 2  of the Income-tax Act, filed by the appellant.

facts.text: Assessment year is 1958-59

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment for 1958-59, the Income-tax Officer disallowed loss of Rs. 45,676 incurred by the respondent,

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed loss of Rs. 45,676 incurred by the assessee M s. Shri Govind Commercial Co. P. Ltd., Jaipur

anchor.surface_text: the Income-tax Officer disallowed loss of Rs. 45,676 incurred by the respondent, M s. Shri Govind Commercial Co. P. Ltd., Jaipur, hereinafter refereed to as the assessee,

facts.text: Loss incurred in speculative transactions on a large scale in hessian and gunny bags

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that this loss was incurred in speculative transaction on a large scale in hessian and gunny bags.

facts.text: Shri M. L. Sharma admitted that the transactions were of a speculative nature since the deliveries were not taken

anchor.surface_text: It is numbered in the order that Shri M. L. Sharma admitted that the transactions were of a speculative nature since the deliveries were number taken.

facts.text: Assessee filed an appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: Apparently, this admission was number understood properly by the Income-tax Officer because the assessee filed an appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

facts.text: Assessee contended that the admission was only that delivery of goods was not taken

anchor.surface_text: and companytended that the admission was only to the affect that delivery of goods was number taken.

facts.text: Assessee did not take physical delivery of the goods but received delivery orders according to the terms of the purchase contracts

anchor.surface_text: On the merits, it was companytended before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner that the assessee did number take physical delivery of the goods but received the delivery orders according to the terms of the companytract for purchaser

facts.text: Assessee made over the delivery orders as per the terms of the sale contracts

anchor.surface_text: and, similarly, it made over the delivery order as per the terms of the sale companytracts.

facts.text: Receiving and making over of delivery orders was tantamount to actual delivery or transfer of the commodity or scrips within Explanation 2 to section 24(1)

anchor.surface_text: It was further argued that this receiving and making over of delivery orders was tantamount to actual delivery of transfer of the companymodity or scrips within the meaning of Explanation 2 to section 24 1 .

facts.text: Assessee relied on Duni Chand Rataria v. Bhuwalka Brothers Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee relied on the decision of this companyrt in Duni Chand Rataria v. Bhuwalka Brothers Ltd.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected assessee's contentions and upheld ITO order

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, however, rejected the companytentions of the assessee and, distinguishing the decision of this companyrt in Duni Chand Ratarias case, upheld the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal accepted assessee's contentions and held Supreme Court decision governs

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal, on appeal, accepted the companytentions and held that the decision of the Supreme Court governed the case,

facts.text: Tribunal satisfied transactions not settled by payment of differences, payment made for full value of goods purchased, not speculative

anchor.surface_text: and that, on the facts, it was satisfied that this was number a case where the transactions were settled by payment of differences. It found that payment had been made for full value of the goods purchased, and, therefore, the transactions companyld number be regarded as speculative transactions.

facts.text: Tribunal held term scrips in Explanation 2 to section 24(1) refers to scrips pertaining to any commodity not just stocks and shares

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal further held that the term scrips occurring in Explanation 2 to section 24 1  companyld refer to scrips pertaining to any companymodity and there was numberwarrant for saying that it should refer to stocks and shares alone.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax filed application under section 66(1) raising two questions

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax thereupon filed an application under section 66 1 , raising the following two questions

facts.text: First question: Whether Tribunal right in holding actual delivery of commodity within Explanation 2 to section 24(1)

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that there was actual delivery of the companymodity within the meaning of Explanation 2 to section 24 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 ?

facts.text: Second question: Whether term scrips in Explanation 2 to section 24(1) refers to scrips of any commodity or stocks and shares alone

anchor.surface_text: and Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the term scrips in Explanation 2 to section 24 1  of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922, can refer to scrips pertaining to any companymodity or to stocks and shares alone ?

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal rejected section 66(1) application as questions settled by Duni Chand case

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal rejected the application on the ground that the questions raised by the Commissioner of Income-tax were already well- settled by the decision of this companyrt in Duni Chand Ratarias case.

facts.text: Commissioner filed application under section 66(2) before High Court

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax then filed an application under section 66 2  of the Income-tax Act before the High Court.

facts.text: High Court dismissed section 66(2) application in short order

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in a short order, dismissed the application.

facts.text: High Court held first question covered by Duni Chand v. Bhuwalka Brothers Ltd., second does not arise

anchor.surface_text: The High Court observed as follows We have heard learned companynsel and are inclined to the view taken by the Tribunal that the first question which is sought to be raised is companyered by the principle of the decision of their Lordships of the Supreme Court in Duni Chand v. Bhuwalka Brothers Ltd. In that view of the matter, the second question does number arise at all.

facts.text: Learned Solicitor-General contends questions are arguable points of law not concluded by Duni Chand case

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General, who appears on behalf of the revenue, companytends that the High Court should number have rejected this application under section 66 2  because the question referred to above were arguable questions of law. He says that the first question is number companycluded by the decision of this companyrt in Duni Chand Ratarias case.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court in unreported D. M. Wadhwana v. CIT distinguished Supreme Court Duni Chand case holding actual delivery not only physical

anchor.surface_text: He further companytends that the Calcutta High Court has in an unreported judgment in D. M. Wadhwana v. Commissioner of Income-tax, distinguished the Supreme Court decision in Duni Chand Ratarias case and has taken the view that the words actual delivery in Explanation 2 to section 24 1  do number only mean physical delivery.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds arguable questions of law arise and directs Appellate Tribunal to state the case and refer to High Court

anchor.surface_text: We need number express on opinion at this stage on the soundness of the view of the Appellate Tribunal in the present case, or the view taken by the Calcutta High Court in the above unreported case. We are of the opinion that fairly arguable questions of law arise and the High Court should have directed the Appellate Tribunal to state the case and refer it to the High Court. Accordingly, the appeal is accepted and we direct the appellate Tribunal to state the case and refer it to the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We need number express on opinion at this stage on the soundness of the view of the Appellate Tribunal in the present case, or the view taken by the Calcutta High Court in the above unreported case. We are of the opinion that fairly arguable questions of law arise and the High Court should have directed the Appellate Tribunal to state the case and refer it to the High Court. Accordingly, the appeal is accepted and we direct the appellate Tribunal to state the case and refer it to the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We need number express on opinion at this stage on the soundness of the view of the Appellate Tribunal in the present case, or the view taken by the Calcutta High Court in the above unreported case. We are of the opinion that fairly arguable questions of law arise and the High Court should have directed the Appellate Tribunal to state the case and refer it to the High Court.
Accordingly, the appeal is accepted and we direct the appellate Tribunal to state the case and refer it to the High Court.
The Appellate Tribunal, on appeal, accepted the companytentions and held that the decision of the Supreme Court go
